elements.content:
<ce:figure id="FIG1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) A view of the structure of [{Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyrpyz)}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) parallel to the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis. The following shading scheme is used throughout: molybdenum, dark polyhedra; copper, light tetrahedra; nitrogen, black spheres; carbon and oxygen, gray spheres. (b) A view of the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, projected onto the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane. (c) The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, viewed parallel to the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis and showing the locations of the water molecules of crystallization.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1a"></ce:link>
<ce:link locator="gr1b"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) A view of the structure of [{Cu2(tpyrpyz)}2Mo8O26]⋅7H2O (1⋅7H2O) parallel to the b-axis. The following shading scheme is used throughout: molybdenum, dark polyhedra; copper, light tetrahedra; nitrogen, black spheres; carbon and oxygen, gray spheres. (b) A view of the structure of 1⋅7H2O, projected onto the ab plane. (c) The structure of 1⋅7H2O, viewed parallel to the a-axis and showing the locations of the water molecules of crystallization.

<ce:figure id="FIG4">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) A view of the {Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyrpyz)}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>+</ce:sup> chain of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. (b) A view of the chain down the axis, illustrating the disposition of the Cu–O bonds.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  (a) A view of the {Cu2(tpyrpyz)} n  2n+ chain of 1⋅7H2O. (b) A view of the chain down the axis, illustrating the disposition of the Cu-O bonds.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="FIG5">
<ce:label>Fig. 5</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Rearrangement pathways and structural intermediates interconnecting the α-, ε-, η-, ζ-, and γ-octamolybdate isomers. Bonds formed between isomers during rearrangements are shown as black lines. Bonds broken during isomer rearrangements are shown as dotted black lines.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr5"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 5  Rearrangement pathways and structural intermediates interconnecting the α-, ε-, η-, ζ-, and γ-octamolybdate isomers. Bonds formed between isomers during rearrangements are shown as black lines. Bonds broken during isomer rearrangements are shown as dotted black lines.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="FIG6">
<ce:label>Fig. 6</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">The rearrangement of the <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> α-isomer (a) to the <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2<ce:italic>h</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> ε-isomer (d) by way of a <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>s</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>-symmetry countercation coordination intermediate (b, c). In a–d, the axis formed through the apical molybdenum atoms is maintained to show the relative rearrangement.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr6"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 6  The rearrangement of the D 3d  α-isomer (a) to the C 2h  ε-isomer (d) by way of a C  s -symmetry countercation coordination intermediate (b, c). In a-d, the axis formed through the apical molybdenum atoms is maintained to show the relative rearrangement.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="FIG7">
<ce:label>Fig. 7</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Crystallographic (top) and 6-31g* geometry-optimized (bottom) structures for the seven isomers. All isomer figures are to scale. Capping (apical) molybdenum atoms are shown in black for those isomers divisible into apical and equatorial regions. Arrows point to the results of the 6-31g* geometry optimizations.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr7"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 7  Crystallographic (top) and 6-31g* geometry-optimized (bottom) structures for the seven isomers. All isomer figures are to scale. Capping (apical) molybdenum atoms are shown in black for those isomers divisible into apical and equatorial regions. Arrows point to the results of the 6-31g* geometry optimizations.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Hydrothermal reactions of CuSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and tetra-2-pyridylpyrazine (tpyrpyz) yield the three-dimensional bimetallic oxide hybrid material [{Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyrpyz)}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{ζ-Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>}]·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O). The framework structure is constructed from {Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyrpyz)}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>+</ce:sup> cationic polymer chains linked through octamolybdate clusters. The ζ-isomer of {Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>, consisting of four octahedral and four square pyramidal sites is present as the cluster building block. There are now seven isomeric forms of the {Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster, and calculations of their relative energies and interconversions are presented. <ce:italic>Crystal data</ce:italic>: C<ce:inf loc="post">48</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">46</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">33</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O), monoclinic <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>=26.678(1), <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>=10.8981(4), and <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>=25.4109(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>=116.855(1)°, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>=6591.2(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>=4, <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">calc</ce:inf>=2.359<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Hydrothermal reactions of CuSO4⋅5H2O, MoO3 and tetra-2-pyridylpyrazine (tpyrpyz) yield the three-dimensional bimetallic oxide hybrid material [{Cu2(tpyrpyz)}2{ζ-Mo8O26}]⋅7H2O (1⋅7H2O). The framework structure is constructed from {Cu2(tpyrpyz)} n  2n+ cationic polymer chains linked through octamolybdate clusters. The ζ-isomer of {Mo8O26}4-, consisting of four octahedral and four square pyramidal sites is present as the cluster building block. There are now seven isomeric forms of the {Mo8O26}4- cluster, and calculations of their relative energies and interconversions are presented. Crystal data: C48H46Cu4Mo8N12O33 (1⋅7H2O), monoclinic C2/c, a=26.678(1), b=10.8981(4), and c=25.4109(9)Å, β=116.855(1)°, V=6591.2(4)Å3, Z=4, D calc=2.359gcm-3.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The extensive compositional range and considerable structural diversity of inorganic oxides  endow these materials with physical properties giving rise to applications ranging from heavy construction to microelectronics . The development of new synthetic strategies for the rational design of these solids is driven by the objectives of discovering new oxide phases and of elaborating their structure–function relationships. In recent years, several strategies have been exploited in the design of new oxide materials. One approach to synthetically modified inorganic oxides focuses on the structure-directing characteristics of organic molecules . Such organic–inorganic hybrid materials combine the unique characteristics of the components to provide novel structural types, as well as new properties arising from the synergistic interplay of the two components . Alternatively, the ‘bottom up’ design of extended oxide materials may rely on ‘self-assembly’ from molecular cluster building blocks , such as the extensive family of polyoxometalates .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The extensive compositional range and considerable structural diversity of inorganic oxides  endow these materials with physical properties giving rise to applications ranging from heavy construction to microelectronics . The development of new synthetic strategies for the rational design of these solids is driven by the objectives of discovering new oxide phases and of elaborating their structure-function relationships. In recent years, several strategies have been exploited in the design of new oxide materials. One approach to synthetically modified inorganic oxides focuses on the structure-directing characteristics of organic molecules . Such organic-inorganic hybrid materials combine the unique characteristics of the components to provide novel structural types, as well as new properties arising from the synergistic interplay of the two components . Alternatively, the ‘bottom up' design of extended oxide materials may rely on ‘self-assembly' from molecular cluster building blocks , such as the extensive family of polyoxometalates .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">During the past decade, we have developed a synthetic strategy which combines these methodologies by employing the organic component as a ligand to a secondary metal cation . Thus, the organic subunit of this multicomponent system serves to fix a number of coordination sites about the secondary metal and to dictate the availability of attachment sites to the oxide clusters. This coordination complex cation not only provides charge compensation, but may also serve space-filling, passivating and structure-directing roles. The coordination preferences of the secondary metal and the geometric and bonding constraints imposed by the ligand may provide structural flexibility, as well as spatial transmission of structural information.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: During the past decade, we have developed a synthetic strategy which combines these methodologies by employing the organic component as a ligand to a secondary metal cation . Thus, the organic subunit of this multicomponent system serves to fix a number of coordination sites about the secondary metal and to dictate the availability of attachment sites to the oxide clusters. This coordination complex cation not only provides charge compensation, but may also serve space-filling, passivating and structure-directing roles. The coordination preferences of the secondary metal and the geometric and bonding constraints imposed by the ligand may provide structural flexibility, as well as spatial transmission of structural information.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">This general strategy has been extensively exploited by us in the development of the chemistry of bimetallic oxides of the copper molybdate family Cu/Mo/O/ligand. It is noteworthy that two distinct subgroups of this family have emerged: (i) a series characterized by polymeric molybdate substructures, generally one- or two-dimensional, decorated by the secondary metal–ligand subunit  and (ii) structures constructed from discrete molybdate clusters, bridged by the secondary metal–ligand component into chains, networks, or frameworks . Of this latter class, composites manifesting embedded octamolybdate clusters , {Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>, are most common. However, a curious feature of the structural chemistry of these phases is the observation of several isomeric forms of the octamolybdate cluster. Thus, the α-isomer has been observed for [{Cu(bpye)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>] ; the β-form for [{Cu(Me-pyz)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>] , [{Cu(Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pyrm)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>] , [{Cu(pyr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-S)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>] , [{Cu(dpa)}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>] , [{Cu(pyr)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>] , and [{Cu(4,4′-bpy)(nic)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>] ; the γ-isomer in [{Cu(en)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>] ; and [{Cu(pyrd)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>] ; and the δ-isomer for [{Cu(4,4′-bpy)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>] . An ε-isomer has been reported for the Ni(II) species [{Ni(4,4′-bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>] . More recently, the η-isomer has been described for the structure of [{Cu(t-Bu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bpy)}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>] . However, the ξ-isomer of [Ni(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>] is in fact a variant of the δ-cluster .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: This general strategy has been extensively exploited by us in the development of the chemistry of bimetallic oxides of the copper molybdate family Cu/Mo/O/ligand. It is noteworthy that two distinct subgroups of this family have emerged: (i) a series characterized by polymeric molybdate substructures, generally one- or two-dimensional, decorated by the secondary metal-ligand subunit  and (ii) structures constructed from discrete molybdate clusters, bridged by the secondary metal-ligand component into chains, networks, or frameworks . Of this latter class, composites manifesting embedded octamolybdate clusters , {Mo8O26}4-, are most common. However, a curious feature of the structural chemistry of these phases is the observation of several isomeric forms of the octamolybdate cluster. Thus, the α-isomer has been observed for [{Cu(bpye)}4Mo8O26] ; the β-form for [{Cu(Me-pyz)}4Mo8O26] , [{Cu(Me2pyrm)}4Mo8O26] , [{Cu(pyr2-S)}4Mo8O26] , [{Cu(dpa)}2Mo8O26] , [{Cu(pyr)}4Mo8O26] , and [{Cu(4,4'-bpy)(nic)(H2O)}2Mo8O26] ; the γ-isomer in [{Cu(en)2}2Mo8O26] ; and [{Cu(pyrd)}4H4Mo8O26] ; and the δ-isomer for [{Cu(4,4'-bpy)}4Mo8O26] . An ε-isomer has been reported for the Ni(II) species [{Ni(4,4'-bpy)2(H2O)2}2Mo8O26] . More recently, the η-isomer has been described for the structure of [{Cu(t-Bu2bpy)}2Mo8O26] . However, the ξ-isomer of [Ni(phen)2]2[Mo8O26] is in fact a variant of the δ-cluster .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">As part of these studies, we have investigated the hydrothermal chemistry of Cu(II) with MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and tetra-2-pyridylpyrazine (tpyrpyz) under a variety of conditions. A three-dimensional copper molybdate has been isolated, [{Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyrpyz)}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) and shown to contain the ζ-isomer of the octamolybdate cluster.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As part of these studies, we have investigated the hydrothermal chemistry of Cu(II) with MoO3 and tetra-2-pyridylpyrazine (tpyrpyz) under a variety of conditions. A three-dimensional copper molybdate has been isolated, [{Cu2(tpyrpyz)}2Mo8O26]⋅7H2O (1⋅7H2O) and shown to contain the ζ-isomer of the octamolybdate cluster.

All starting materials were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. Water was distilled above 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MΩ in-house using a Barnstead model 525 Biopure distilled water center. Infrared spectra were obtained on a Perkin–Elmer 1600 series FTIR spectrometer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental methods

Syntheses and spectroscopy

Syntheses were carried out in Parr acid digestion bombs with 23 ml poly(tetrafluoroethylene) liners. All starting materials were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. Water was distilled above 0.3MΩ in-house using a Barnstead model 525 Biopure distilled water center. Infrared spectra were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer 1600 series FTIR spectrometer.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis of [{Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyrpyz)}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A mixture of CuSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.046 g, 0.19 mmol), MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.027 g, 0.19 mmol), tetra-4-pyridylpyrazine (0.108 g, 0.28 mmol) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (10.0 g, 0.56 mol) in the mole ratio 1:1:1.5:3000 was heated at 120 °C for 48 h. Orange crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O were obtained in 30% yield based on molybdenum. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3400 (m, br), 1380 (s), 910 (s, br), 850 (m), 810 (s).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [{Cu2(tpyrpyz)}2Mo8O26]⋅7H2O (1⋅7H2O)

A mixture of CuSO4⋅5H2O (0.046 g, 0.19 mmol), MoO3 (0.027 g, 0.19 mmol), tetra-4-pyridylpyrazine (0.108 g, 0.28 mmol) and H2O (10.0 g, 0.56 mol) in the mole ratio 1:1:1.5:3000 was heated at 120 °C for 48 h. Orange crystals of 1⋅7H2O were obtained in 30% yield based on molybdenum. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3400 (m, br), 1380 (s), 910 (s, br), 850 (m), 810 (s).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Crystallographic data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were collected with a Bruker P4 diffractometer equipped with a SMART CCD system  and using Mo<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:inf loc="post">α</ce:inf> radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The data were collected at 90 K and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects . Absorption corrections were made using SADABS . The structure solution and refinement were carried out using the SHELXTL  crystallographic software package. The structures were solved using direct methods, and all of the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the initial solution. After locating all of the non-hydrogen atoms in each structure, the model was refined against <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, initially using isotropic then anisotropic thermal displacement parameters, until the final value of <ce:italic>Δ</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf> was less than 0.001. Crystal data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL1"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond lengths and angles for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are collected in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL2"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Crystallographic data for 1 were collected with a Bruker P4 diffractometer equipped with a SMART CCD system  and using MoKα radiation (λ=0.71073Å). The data were collected at 90 K and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects . Absorption corrections were made using SADABS . The structure solution and refinement were carried out using the SHELXTL  crystallographic software package. The structures were solved using direct methods, and all of the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the initial solution. After locating all of the non-hydrogen atoms in each structure, the model was refined against F 2, initially using isotropic then anisotropic thermal displacement parameters, until the final value of Δ/σ max was less than 0.001. Crystal data for 1 are summarized in  . Selected bond lengths and angles for compound 1 are collected in  .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">
<ce:italic>CCDC reference number</ce:italic>. See <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="http://www.rsc.org/suppdata/dt/bl/bl04965h/" xlink:type="simple">http://www.rsc.org/suppdata/dt/bl/bl04965h/</ce:inter-ref> for crystallographic data in CIF or other electronic format.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Computational methods</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The computational study of the seven isomers consisted of both single-point energy calculations and geometry optimizations at the restricted Hartree–Fock (RHF) level of theory using 3-21g and 6-31g* basis sets for oxygen and the SBKJC effective core potential for molybdenum . Calculations were performed using the PC GAMESS version  of the GAMESS-US Quantum Chemistry package . The atomic coordinates of each isomer used for the single-point energy calculations were taken from among the reported crystal structures referenced in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL3"></ce:float-anchor>. The single-point energies were calculated in the absence of symmetry restrictions. A number of crystal structures containing the same isomeric form of the α-, β-, γ-, and δ-octamolybdates exist as shown in . The subtle differences that come with packing environment and countercation were neglected and one set of coordinates for each isomer was chosen as representative of the rest. Geometry optimizations were performed using the highest symmetry point group of each isomer as determined from both prior studies  and analysis of the selected coordinates.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
CCDC reference number. See http://www.rsc.org/suppdata/dt/bl/bl04965h/ for crystallographic data in CIF or other electronic format.

Computational methods

The computational study of the seven isomers consisted of both single-point energy calculations and geometry optimizations at the restricted Hartree-Fock (RHF) level of theory using 3-21g and 6-31g* basis sets for oxygen and the SBKJC effective core potential for molybdenum . Calculations were performed using the PC GAMESS version  of the GAMESS-US Quantum Chemistry package . The atomic coordinates of each isomer used for the single-point energy calculations were taken from among the reported crystal structures referenced in  . The single-point energies were calculated in the absence of symmetry restrictions. A number of crystal structures containing the same isomeric form of the α-, β-, γ-, and δ-octamolybdates exist as shown in . The subtle differences that come with packing environment and countercation were neglected and one set of coordinates for each isomer was chosen as representative of the rest. Geometry optimizations were performed using the highest symmetry point group of each isomer as determined from both prior studies  and analysis of the selected coordinates.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis and structural studies</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The bimetallic oxide of this study was prepared by conventional hydrothermal methods, which avoid thermal decomposition of the organic component while providing conditions which overcome the differential solubilities of the organic and inorganic components and which are optimal for crystal growth . In this fashion, the reaction of CuSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and tetra-2-pyridylpyrazine yielded [{Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyrpyz)}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) in 60% yield as dark blue crystals. The infrared spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibited strong bands in the 800–960 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> range, attributed to <ce:italic>υ</ce:italic>(MoO) and <ce:italic>υ</ce:italic>(M–O–Mo) [M=Cu or Mo]. A group of peaks in the 1000–1500 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> region is characteristic of the tpyrpyz ligand.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and structural studies

The bimetallic oxide of this study was prepared by conventional hydrothermal methods, which avoid thermal decomposition of the organic component while providing conditions which overcome the differential solubilities of the organic and inorganic components and which are optimal for crystal growth . In this fashion, the reaction of CuSO4⋅5H2O, MoO3 and tetra-2-pyridylpyrazine yielded [{Cu2(tpyrpyz)}2Mo8O26]⋅7H2O (1⋅7H2O) in 60% yield as dark blue crystals. The infrared spectrum of 1 exhibited strong bands in the 800-960 cm-1 range, attributed to υ(MoO) and υ(M-O-Mo) [M=Cu or Mo]. A group of peaks in the 1000-1500 cm-1 region is characteristic of the tpyrpyz ligand.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor>, the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a three-dimensional framework, constructed from {Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyrpyz)}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>+</ce:sup> chains linked through discrete octamolybdate clusters. The {Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyrpyz)}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:sup> chains extend along the crystallographic <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis in the <ce:italic>ac</ce:italic>, as shown in . Each chain is linked to adjacent chains through the molybdate clusters. While the projection onto the <ce:italic>ac</ce:italic> plane illustrates the linking of a given chain to two adjacent chains, the view parallel to the chain axis, that is, the projection onto the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane shown in , reveals that each chain is linked to four neighboring chains through the octamolybdate subunits, resulting in structural propagation in three dimensions. The view of  also illustrates the cavities produced by the {Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>} scaffolding which are occupied by the pyridyl rings, which project from the four edges of the Cu(I)–ligand chains.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As shown in  , the structure of 1 is a three-dimensional framework, constructed from {Cu2(tpyrpyz)} n  2n+ chains linked through discrete octamolybdate clusters. The {Cu2(tpyrpyz)} n  2n  chains extend along the crystallographic c-axis in the ac, as shown in . Each chain is linked to adjacent chains through the molybdate clusters. While the projection onto the ac plane illustrates the linking of a given chain to two adjacent chains, the view parallel to the chain axis, that is, the projection onto the ab plane shown in , reveals that each chain is linked to four neighboring chains through the octamolybdate subunits, resulting in structural propagation in three dimensions. The view of  also illustrates the cavities produced by the {Cu2Mo8O26} scaffolding which are occupied by the pyridyl rings, which project from the four edges of the Cu(I)-ligand chains.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">As shown in , the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O may be described alternatively as inorganic copper–molybdenum oxide layers, aligned parallel to the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane, with the organic tethers running in the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-direction. In this perspective, the structure is partitioned into inorganic domains linked through organic regions. The water molecules of crystallization are seen to occupy the interlamellar region.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As shown in , the structure of 1⋅7H2O may be described alternatively as inorganic copper-molybdenum oxide layers, aligned parallel to the ab plane, with the organic tethers running in the a-direction. In this perspective, the structure is partitioned into inorganic domains linked through organic regions. The water molecules of crystallization are seen to occupy the interlamellar region.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The molybdate substructure is the ζ-isomer of {Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>, which consists of four {MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>} octahedra and four {MoO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>} square pyramids linked through corner- and edge-sharing interactions. The structure may be described as a ring constructed from two pairs of edge-sharing octahedra linked through two edge- and corner-sharing square pyramidal sites and capped on either face by square pyramids. The octahedra and square pyramids of the equatorial ring all exhibit two terminal oxo-groups, while the two capping square pyramids have a single terminal oxo-group. Each cluster contributes a total of four polyhedral vertices to two adjacent {Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyrpyz)}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>+</ce:sup> chains. These corner-sharing interactions are provided through the terminal oxo-groups {MoO} of two octahedra and two square pyramids located in the equatorial ring of the cluster.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The molybdate substructure is the ζ-isomer of {Mo8O26}4-, which consists of four {MoO6} octahedra and four {MoO5} square pyramids linked through corner- and edge-sharing interactions. The structure may be described as a ring constructed from two pairs of edge-sharing octahedra linked through two edge- and corner-sharing square pyramidal sites and capped on either face by square pyramids. The octahedra and square pyramids of the equatorial ring all exhibit two terminal oxo-groups, while the two capping square pyramids have a single terminal oxo-group. Each cluster contributes a total of four polyhedral vertices to two adjacent {Cu2(tpyrpyz)} n  2n+ chains. These corner-sharing interactions are provided through the terminal oxo-groups {MoO} of two octahedra and two square pyramids located in the equatorial ring of the cluster.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor>, the structure of the ζ-isomer is closely related to the α-, and η-isomers. The α-isomer consists of a ring of six octahedra, capped on top and bottom by two tetrahedra, while the η-isomer is a ring of six octahedra with two capping square pyramids. The ζ-isomer exhibits a more open structure in which there are two sets of edge-sharing pairs of octahedra, linked through two pairs of edge-sharing square pyramids. There are no μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-oxo groups bridging two square pyramidal sites and one octahedral site and two μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> interactions between two octahedra and one square pyramid.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As shown in  , the structure of the ζ-isomer is closely related to the α-, and η-isomers. The α-isomer consists of a ring of six octahedra, capped on top and bottom by two tetrahedra, while the η-isomer is a ring of six octahedra with two capping square pyramids. The ζ-isomer exhibits a more open structure in which there are two sets of edge-sharing pairs of octahedra, linked through two pairs of edge-sharing square pyramids. There are no μ3-oxo groups bridging two square pyramidal sites and one octahedral site and two μ3 interactions between two octahedra and one square pyramid.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Although a previously reported octamolybdate structure [{Ni(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>] , erroneously designated as the ξ-isomer, was described in terms of four octahedral and four square pyramidal building blocks as for the ζ-isomer of this study, closer inspection reveals that this compound is actually a δ-isomer. Two square pyramidal sites are in fact octahedral if consistent Mo–O bond ranges are adopted.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Although a previously reported octamolybdate structure [{Ni(phen)2}2Mo8O26] , erroneously designated as the ξ-isomer, was described in terms of four octahedral and four square pyramidal building blocks as for the ζ-isomer of this study, closer inspection reveals that this compound is actually a δ-isomer. Two square pyramidal sites are in fact octahedral if consistent Mo-O bond ranges are adopted.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">It is also noteworthy that the ε-, ζ- and η-forms are related by simple compression of the cluster along two Mo⋯O or four Mo⋯O bond axes, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>. While this observation is reminiscent of the ‘bond stretch’ isomer controversy of the 1990s , it should be noted that the representative structures for these octamolybdates, [{Ni(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(4,4′-bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>], [{Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyrpyz)}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>] and [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(t-Bu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>], do not exhibit isolated molecular anion clusters, but rather clusters embedded within two-, three- and one-dimensional architectures, respectively. Consequently, the relatively small bond length differences of 0.1–0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å along the relevant Mo⋯O axes may be accounted for by packing forces and the structural demands of coordination through oxo-groups to the secondary metal–ligand components of the extended structures. Consequently, the ε-, ζ- and η-forms result from the ‘breathing’ of a common architecture in response to the environmental constraints on the cluster and may be more convincingly considered structural variants, rather than distinct isomeric prototypes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is also noteworthy that the ε-, ζ- and η-forms are related by simple compression of the cluster along two Mo⋯O or four Mo⋯O bond axes, as shown in  . While this observation is reminiscent of the ‘bond stretch' isomer controversy of the 1990s , it should be noted that the representative structures for these octamolybdates, [{Ni(H2O)(4,4'-bpy)2}2Mo8O26], [{Cu2(tpyrpyz)}2Mo8O26] and [Cu2(t-Bu2bpy)2Mo8O26], do not exhibit isolated molecular anion clusters, but rather clusters embedded within two-, three- and one-dimensional architectures, respectively. Consequently, the relatively small bond length differences of 0.1-0.2Å along the relevant Mo⋯O axes may be accounted for by packing forces and the structural demands of coordination through oxo-groups to the secondary metal-ligand components of the extended structures. Consequently, the ε-, ζ- and η-forms result from the ‘breathing' of a common architecture in response to the environmental constraints on the cluster and may be more convincingly considered structural variants, rather than distinct isomeric prototypes.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The {Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyrpyz)}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>+</ce:sup> component is a double chain of Cu(I) tetrahedra, linked through tpyrpyz ligands ()<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG4"></ce:float-anchor>. There are two distinct Cu(I) sites. The first is an elongated {CuN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} tetrahedron. The coordination geometry at this site is defined by the nitrogen donors from two tpyrpyz ligands, each acting as a bidentate chelate through a pyrazine and a pyridyl nitrogen donor. The second copper site is a distorted {CuN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} tetrahedron, with the Cu(I) center coordinating to pyridyl nitrogens from two adjacent tpypyz ligands of the chain and two terminal oxo-groups of a molybdate cluster. The oxo-groups involved in Cu–O–Mo bridging are located on the ring octahedra and square pyramids.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The {Cu2(tpyrpyz)} n  2n+ component is a double chain of Cu(I) tetrahedra, linked through tpyrpyz ligands (). There are two distinct Cu(I) sites. The first is an elongated {CuN4} tetrahedron. The coordination geometry at this site is defined by the nitrogen donors from two tpyrpyz ligands, each acting as a bidentate chelate through a pyrazine and a pyridyl nitrogen donor. The second copper site is a distorted {CuN2O2} tetrahedron, with the Cu(I) center coordinating to pyridyl nitrogens from two adjacent tpypyz ligands of the chain and two terminal oxo-groups of a molybdate cluster. The oxo-groups involved in Cu-O-Mo bridging are located on the ring octahedra and square pyramids.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Each tpyrpyz ligand bridges four Cu(I) sites, two in bidentate mode and two in monodentate mode. The {CuN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} sites are embedded within the organic domain of the chain, while the {CuN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} sites project above and below the chain to coordinate to the {Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> clusters.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Each tpyrpyz ligand bridges four Cu(I) sites, two in bidentate mode and two in monodentate mode. The {CuN4} sites are embedded within the organic domain of the chain, while the {CuN2O2} sites project above and below the chain to coordinate to the {Mo8O26}4- clusters.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Single-point energies and isomerization pathways</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The relative single-point energies of the seven isomers with both the 3-21g and 6-31g* oxygen basis sets are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL4"></ce:float-anchor>. All values are reported relative to the δ-isomer, which is the lowest energy form in the RHF calculations. The calculations agree on the relative ordering of the energy extrema (the δ-, η-, and β-isomers) and the relative position of the ε-isomer. The major differences are in the ordering of the α-, ζ-, and γ-isomer energies and the energy ranges of the 3-21g and 6-31g* structures. With both basis sets, the ε-, ζ-, and γ-isomers occur within a narrow energy range (ε–γ=21.96 kJ/mol for 6-31g*; ζ–γ=30.53 kJ/mol for 3-21g). The α-isomer is included, at 15.42 kJ/mol, in this narrow energy series for the 3-21g calculations but is excluded, at 43.01 kJ/mol, in the 6-31g* series.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Single-point energies and isomerization pathways

The relative single-point energies of the seven isomers with both the 3-21g and 6-31g* oxygen basis sets are given in  . All values are reported relative to the δ-isomer, which is the lowest energy form in the RHF calculations. The calculations agree on the relative ordering of the energy extrema (the δ-, η-, and β-isomers) and the relative position of the ε-isomer. The major differences are in the ordering of the α-, ζ-, and γ-isomer energies and the energy ranges of the 3-21g and 6-31g* structures. With both basis sets, the ε-, ζ-, and γ-isomers occur within a narrow energy range (ε-γ=21.96 kJ/mol for 6-31g*; ζ-γ=30.53 kJ/mol for 3-21g). The α-isomer is included, at 15.42 kJ/mol, in this narrow energy series for the 3-21g calculations but is excluded, at 43.01 kJ/mol, in the 6-31g* series.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The range of 6-31g* single-point energies is nearly twice that for the 3-21g calculations and occurs as a result of larger energy differences between certain isomers or groups of isomers. These energy differences result in a reordering of the α-isomer, a larger separation between the energy of the η-isomer and the ε-, ζ-, γ-isomer series, and an increased separation between the η- and β-isomers. Also provided for comparison in  are the relative energies of six of the isomers (the new ζ-isomer of this study is absent) based on DFT single-point energy calculations of octamolybdate crystallographic coordinates with a triple-ζ quality STO basis set (including relativistic effects) and the BP86 (a hybrid Becke 1988 exchange and Perdew 1986 correlation) functional using the ADF 2000.02 program . Here, the β-isomer is still found to be highest in energy, but the δ-isomer is replaced by the α-isomer as the absolute (single-point) minimum. While the narrower energy range of the DFT calculations is consistent with the 3-21g calculations, the ordering of the isomers based on the crystallographic coordinates is more consistent with the 6-31g* calculations.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The range of 6-31g* single-point energies is nearly twice that for the 3-21g calculations and occurs as a result of larger energy differences between certain isomers or groups of isomers. These energy differences result in a reordering of the α-isomer, a larger separation between the energy of the η-isomer and the ε-, ζ-, γ-isomer series, and an increased separation between the η- and β-isomers. Also provided for comparison in  are the relative energies of six of the isomers (the new ζ-isomer of this study is absent) based on DFT single-point energy calculations of octamolybdate crystallographic coordinates with a triple-ζ quality STO basis set (including relativistic effects) and the BP86 (a hybrid Becke 1988 exchange and Perdew 1986 correlation) functional using the ADF 2000.02 program . Here, the β-isomer is still found to be highest in energy, but the δ-isomer is replaced by the α-isomer as the absolute (single-point) minimum. While the narrower energy range of the DFT calculations is consistent with the 3-21g calculations, the ordering of the isomers based on the crystallographic coordinates is more consistent with the 6-31g* calculations.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The basis set has a significant effect on the single-point energies and ordering of the isomers. The results of the 6-31g* calculations are favored without qualification based both on the higher quality of the 6-31g basis set and the added d-polarization function, which together add greater flexibility to account for (1) longer range bonding interactions between component polyhedra and (2) the anionic character of the molybdate oxygen atoms. The analyses of trends are based on the 6-31g* energies unless otherwise stated. From the single-point energy calculations alone, a number of trends stand out that highlight the differences in isomer shape, choice of cation, and crystal environment for these seven structures, specifically where sets of isomers are known to be related by simple structural rearrangements or where conceptually straightforward rearrangements can be imprinted on isomer sets. These trends will be further elaborated on in the discussion of the optimized structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The basis set has a significant effect on the single-point energies and ordering of the isomers. The results of the 6-31g* calculations are favored without qualification based both on the higher quality of the 6-31g basis set and the added d-polarization function, which together add greater flexibility to account for (1) longer range bonding interactions between component polyhedra and (2) the anionic character of the molybdate oxygen atoms. The analyses of trends are based on the 6-31g* energies unless otherwise stated. From the single-point energy calculations alone, a number of trends stand out that highlight the differences in isomer shape, choice of cation, and crystal environment for these seven structures, specifically where sets of isomers are known to be related by simple structural rearrangements or where conceptually straightforward rearrangements can be imprinted on isomer sets. These trends will be further elaborated on in the discussion of the optimized structures.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The low stability of the β-isomer results from electrostatic interactions that occur in a tightly packed structure of eight octahedral subunits which include two five-coordinate (μ<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>) oxygen atoms . The tightly packed β-isomer and more open α-isomer encompass nearly the complete energy range of the calculated structures. Their interconversion at low pH in the presence of various countercations consequently demonstrates just how energetically approachable all seven isomers are in solution and how the subtle choice of environment, be it crystal or solution, can direct the formation of specific isomers. It is also consistent with previous studies that the γ-isomer resides intermediate between the β- and α-isomers in energy, as its structure closely resembles that of the intermediate proposed by Klemperer and Shum to explain the interconversion of the α- and β-isomer forms . The relative stability of the δ-isomer from single-point energy calculations is unusual only because this isomer occurs less frequently in crystal forms relative to both the α- and β-isomers. These considerations are explored in further detail in the discussion of the optimized structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The low stability of the β-isomer results from electrostatic interactions that occur in a tightly packed structure of eight octahedral subunits which include two five-coordinate (μ5) oxygen atoms . The tightly packed β-isomer and more open α-isomer encompass nearly the complete energy range of the calculated structures. Their interconversion at low pH in the presence of various countercations consequently demonstrates just how energetically approachable all seven isomers are in solution and how the subtle choice of environment, be it crystal or solution, can direct the formation of specific isomers. It is also consistent with previous studies that the γ-isomer resides intermediate between the β- and α-isomers in energy, as its structure closely resembles that of the intermediate proposed by Klemperer and Shum to explain the interconversion of the α- and β-isomer forms . The relative stability of the δ-isomer from single-point energy calculations is unusual only because this isomer occurs less frequently in crystal forms relative to both the α- and β-isomers. These considerations are explored in further detail in the discussion of the optimized structures.

The large energy difference between the ε- and η-isomers (92.6 kJ/mol) is attributed to the presence of different countercations (Cu(I) in the ε-isomer, Ni(II) in the η-isomer) and the degree of rearrangement along the <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>

elements.clean_text: The α-isomer has approximate D 3d  symmetry in the crystal, making it the most highly symmetric of the seven isomers, as shown in . Conversion of the D 3d  α-isomer to the nearly C 2h  ε- and η-isomers occurs by way of a sliding motion of the two capping α-tetrahedral MoO4 units along a D 3d  mirror plane as shown in  . Conversion to the C  i  symmetry ζ- and γ-isomers from the α-isomer can be considered as a combination of (1) a C 2h  sliding deformation of the capping tetrahedral units to an ε-isomeric form and (2) a separation of these two capping units along the axis perpendicular to the C 2h  mirror plane. The reordering of the α-isomer in the 6-31g* single-point energy series is consistent with this pathway for isomer formation in the presence of coordinating counterions that serve to initiate the required structural deformations. Specifically, the binding of a single cation to a pair of equatorial terminal oxygens in the D 3d  α-isomer () removes the threefold symmetry of this isomer to form a C  s  coordination complex with only the mirror plane (neglecting the countercation ligands) relating atoms (). The deformation along this mirror plane by cation binding () then orients the opposite pair of terminal oxygen atoms so as to prefer a similar cation-binding motif (). Cation binding is then seen as the means for deformation of the high-symmetry α- to the lower-symmetry ε- and η-isomers. The large energy difference between the ε- and η-isomers (92.6 kJ/mol) is attributed to the presence of different countercations (Cu(I) in the ε-isomer, Ni(II) in the η-isomer) and the degree of rearrangement along the C 2h  mirror plane that must occur in order to maximize the terminal oxygen/cation interaction for each. With this rearrangement completed, the formation of the ζ- and γ-isomers requires other crystal elements to deform the C 2h  structures along the perpendicular axis.

elements.clean_text: The narrow energy range associated with the series ε→ζ→γ, and, specifically, the placement of the ζ-isomer between the ε- and γ-isomers, highlights a structural motif resulting from a deformation of a C 2h  structure to a C  i  structure through a dislocation of the two capping square pyramidal molybdenum polyhedra perpendicular to the mirror plane of the C 2h  ε-isomer. In this sense, the ζ-isomer can be considered as an intermediate between a C  i  γ-isomer and a more stable C 2h  ε-isomer, just as the γ-isomer can be considered as a structural intermediate in α- to β-isomer conversion. This new ε→ζ→γ series occurs over a much smaller energy range and requires a far simpler rearrangement scheme to describe interconversion.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Geometry optimizations</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Geometry optimizations were performed using symmetry constraints in order to both reduce computational cost and restrict the flexibility of the seven isomers in the search for minimum energy structures. As a result, an optimizing structure could not go to a lower symmetry during the optimization than the symmetry specified in the input structure. Geometry optimizations were performed first with the 3-21g oxygen basis set both to rapidly clean the symmetry-restricted input structures prior to the more robust (and markedly more computationally demanding) 6-31g* optimizations and gauge the importance of the basis set on the calculation of the various structural features of the seven isomers. The atomic coordinates of the 3-21g optimized structures were used as the starting coordinates for the 6-31g* calculations. The final set of 6-31g* atomic coordinates were then used for geometry optimizations in the absence of symmetry restrictions (<ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> input format) to confirm that the isomers were, at least, local minima and that the symmetry constrains were not forcing atoms from more stable nearby positions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Geometry optimizations

Geometry optimizations were performed using symmetry constraints in order to both reduce computational cost and restrict the flexibility of the seven isomers in the search for minimum energy structures. As a result, an optimizing structure could not go to a lower symmetry during the optimization than the symmetry specified in the input structure. Geometry optimizations were performed first with the 3-21g oxygen basis set both to rapidly clean the symmetry-restricted input structures prior to the more robust (and markedly more computationally demanding) 6-31g* optimizations and gauge the importance of the basis set on the calculation of the various structural features of the seven isomers. The atomic coordinates of the 3-21g optimized structures were used as the starting coordinates for the 6-31g* calculations. The final set of 6-31g* atomic coordinates were then used for geometry optimizations in the absence of symmetry restrictions (C 1 input format) to confirm that the isomers were, at least, local minima and that the symmetry constrains were not forcing atoms from more stable nearby positions.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>3-21g Optimizations</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The relative energies of the seven optimized isomers with the 3-21g oxygen basis set are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL5"></ce:float-anchor>. The most noteworthy results of these optimizations are the pairings of the (γ, ζ) and (η, ε) isomers, reducing the total number of unique isomers to five. The ζ- and γ-isomers both optimize to an expanded <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>i</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>-symmetry γ-structure consistent with the expansion observed for the 6-31g* γ-structure shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG7"></ce:float-anchor>. The optimized (γ, ζ)-isomer pair lies considerably lower in energy (47.66 kJ/mol) than the optimized δ-isomer, making (γ, ζ) the lowest energy structure in the 3-21g series. The ζ-isomer, as a structural intermediate between the ε- and γ-isomers (), would be expected to optimize to either of the two if it was not a local minimum. The ζ-isomer rearrangement to the γ-isomer is consistent with the γ-isomer being 54.7 kJ/mol lower in total energy than the ε-isomer in the 3-21g optimizations. The minimization of the <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2<ce:italic>h</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>-symmetry η- and ε-isomers to the same structure in the absence of their respective countercations (ε-isomer Cu(I) and η-isomer Ni(II)) is consistent with the rearrangement scheme proposed in . In this pair, the removal of the countercations and other external forces in the more strained η-isomer results in a relaxation back to the more open ε-isomer. The (ε, η) pair optimizes to a <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2<ce:italic>h</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> ε-structure in which the η-isomer bonds connecting each of the pair of apical oxygen atoms to two equatorial molybdenum octahedra are lost in favor of a more enlarged central cavity. The removal of the <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2<ce:italic>h</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> symmetry restrictions and subsequent energy minimization of the ε-isomer did not yield a lower energy structure, indicating it is a local minimum with this basis set. Consequently, a barrier exists between the stable ε- and γ-isomers and, with the 3-21g basis set, the ζ-isomer exists along a rearrangement pathway favoring γ-isomer formation (). The β-isomer remains highest in energy, although the energy gap between it and the α-isomer has decreased 35 kJ/mol relative to the experimental atomic coordinates.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
3-21g Optimizations

The relative energies of the seven optimized isomers with the 3-21g oxygen basis set are given in  . The most noteworthy results of these optimizations are the pairings of the (γ, ζ) and (η, ε) isomers, reducing the total number of unique isomers to five. The ζ- and γ-isomers both optimize to an expanded C  i -symmetry γ-structure consistent with the expansion observed for the 6-31g* γ-structure shown in  . The optimized (γ, ζ)-isomer pair lies considerably lower in energy (47.66 kJ/mol) than the optimized δ-isomer, making (γ, ζ) the lowest energy structure in the 3-21g series. The ζ-isomer, as a structural intermediate between the ε- and γ-isomers (), would be expected to optimize to either of the two if it was not a local minimum. The ζ-isomer rearrangement to the γ-isomer is consistent with the γ-isomer being 54.7 kJ/mol lower in total energy than the ε-isomer in the 3-21g optimizations. The minimization of the C 2h -symmetry η- and ε-isomers to the same structure in the absence of their respective countercations (ε-isomer Cu(I) and η-isomer Ni(II)) is consistent with the rearrangement scheme proposed in . In this pair, the removal of the countercations and other external forces in the more strained η-isomer results in a relaxation back to the more open ε-isomer. The (ε, η) pair optimizes to a C 2h  ε-structure in which the η-isomer bonds connecting each of the pair of apical oxygen atoms to two equatorial molybdenum octahedra are lost in favor of a more enlarged central cavity. The removal of the C 2h  symmetry restrictions and subsequent energy minimization of the ε-isomer did not yield a lower energy structure, indicating it is a local minimum with this basis set. Consequently, a barrier exists between the stable ε- and γ-isomers and, with the 3-21g basis set, the ζ-isomer exists along a rearrangement pathway favoring γ-isomer formation (). The β-isomer remains highest in energy, although the energy gap between it and the α-isomer has decreased 35 kJ/mol relative to the experimental atomic coordinates.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The symmetry-unique Mo–O bond lengths and bond orders for the α-, β-, γ-, and δ-isomers (the four isomers obtained from the 6-31g* optimizations and those for which a more detailed analysis is provided in the next section) are given for the 3-21g structures in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL6"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL7"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL8"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL9"></ce:float-anchor>. Despite the limited quality of the basis set and the specific lack of polarization and diffuse functions to better describe the oxygen anions and molybdenum-oxygen bonds, the 3-21g bond lengths and bond orders are in remarkably good agreement with most of the experimental distances. Of the 55 unique Mo–O bonds in the four isomers, 50 differ from their crystallographic distances by less than 0.090<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The two bond lengths that differ by more than 0.250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å occur in the γ- and β-isomers, which both undergo large structural changes that result in the displacement of molybdenum polyhedra from their crystallographic positions as also observed in the 6-31g* structures shown in . These features may, however, be a result of electrostatic or packing forces affecting the position of the most easily displaced molybdenum polyhedra in the crystal and not due to a limitation of the computational method. These structural changes with optimization are also seen in the 6-31g* calculations and their examination is saved for the more detailed analysis with the 6-31g* basis set.</ce:para>

Despite the limited quality of the basis set and the specific lack of polarization and diffuse functions to better describe the oxygen anions and molybdenum-oxygen bonds, the 3-21g bond lengths and bond orders are in remarkably good agreement with most of the experimental distances. elements.content: <ce:section-title>6-31g* Optimizations and structural/electronic considerations</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The relative energies of the seven optimized isomers with the 6-31g* oxygen basis set are given in . The optimization of different isomers to identical energy minima is continued in the 3-21g-derived 6-31g* structures while the ordering of the energies of the new isomer groupings are consistent with the 6-31g* single-point and DFT energies. The structural and electronic features of the four unique 6-31g* isomers are examined here in detail, including both the relationships of the isomer sets to one another based on the rearrangement scheme shown in  and the charge densities and bond orders of these symmetric minimum energy structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
6-31g* Optimizations and structural/electronic considerations

The relative energies of the seven optimized isomers with the 6-31g* oxygen basis set are given in . The optimization of different isomers to identical energy minima is continued in the 3-21g-derived 6-31g* structures while the ordering of the energies of the new isomer groupings are consistent with the 6-31g* single-point and DFT energies. The structural and electronic features of the four unique 6-31g* isomers are examined here in detail, including both the relationships of the isomer sets to one another based on the rearrangement scheme shown in  and the charge densities and bond orders of these symmetric minimum energy structures.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The differences in energies and orderings of the 6-31g* structures relative to the 3-21g starting structures are consistent with those found for the single-point energy differences between the two basis sets. The δ-isomer is found to be the minimum energy structure in the 6-31g* optimizations, just as it was found to be the minimum energy structure in the single-point energy calculations. Furthermore, this reordering relative to the 3-21g calculations agrees with the DFT energy minimization of the δ-isomer. Across all energy calculations and geometry optimizations, the β-isomer is the least stable structure. The 114 kJ/mol energy difference between the β-isomer and its nearest neighbor (γ-isomer) is the largest of any gap among all of the calculations, although this large difference is attributed to the grouping of the remaining isomers into three closely spaced energy minima. The (γ, ζ)-isomer grouping is carried over from the 3-21g optimization to yield a distinctly γ-structure (). The rearrangement of the relative energies places this pair above the α- and δ-isomers, which is again consistent with the single-point energy calculations and the ordering of the DFT energies. The energy gap between the lowest-energy δ-isomer and the (γ, ζ)-isomer pair is decreased by 63 kJ/mol in the geometry optimizations and can be taken as a result of large changes in the γ-isomer geometry during the optimization to a less compacted form. The 10 kJ/mol DFT energy difference calculated for the <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>i</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>-symmetry (γ, ζ) pair is small, highlighting the similarity of these two structures. In the DFT study, however, the γ-isomer was found to be unstable in its crystal form and rearranged in the energy minimization to a more open ζ-like form. The 6-31g* optimization of the <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>i</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>-symmetry γ-isomer resulted in a small elongation of the central Mo–O bonds in the cluster and a more pronounced expansion along the length of the molecule to yield a clearly γ-like structure in contrast to the OFT study. This difference between the DFT and HF calculations seemed unusual enough to warrant a recalculation of the ζ-isomer from its symmetry-restricted <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>i</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>-crystal coordinates to determine if the resulting 3-21g (γ, ζ)-isomer pair may have been due to the choice of basis set. The new 6-31g* ζ-isomer was found to optimize, as was also found for the 3-21g (ε, η)-isomer pair, to the <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>-symmetry α-isomer. With the optimization of the new ζ-, α-, and (ε, η)-isomers to a <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> minimum, the final count of unique isomers with the 6-31g* basis set is reduced to four. The new (α, ε, η, ζ)-isomer series lies 24 kJ/mol above the single δ-isomer, a difference in agreement with the 23 kJ/mol difference found for the 6-31g* single-point energy difference between the α- and δ-isomers. With the exception of the large energy difference between the α-isomer and the local minimum ε-isomer in the DFT calculations, the ordering and relative groupings of the seven isomers into four clearly unique structures are consistent with the DFT results.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The differences in energies and orderings of the 6-31g* structures relative to the 3-21g starting structures are consistent with those found for the single-point energy differences between the two basis sets. The δ-isomer is found to be the minimum energy structure in the 6-31g* optimizations, just as it was found to be the minimum energy structure in the single-point energy calculations. Furthermore, this reordering relative to the 3-21g calculations agrees with the DFT energy minimization of the δ-isomer. Across all energy calculations and geometry optimizations, the β-isomer is the least stable structure. The 114 kJ/mol energy difference between the β-isomer and its nearest neighbor (γ-isomer) is the largest of any gap among all of the calculations, although this large difference is attributed to the grouping of the remaining isomers into three closely spaced energy minima. The (γ, ζ)-isomer grouping is carried over from the 3-21g optimization to yield a distinctly γ-structure (). The rearrangement of the relative energies places this pair above the α- and δ-isomers, which is again consistent with the single-point energy calculations and the ordering of the DFT energies. The energy gap between the lowest-energy δ-isomer and the (γ, ζ)-isomer pair is decreased by 63 kJ/mol in the geometry optimizations and can be taken as a result of large changes in the γ-isomer geometry during the optimization to a less compacted form. The 10 kJ/mol DFT energy difference calculated for the C  i -symmetry (γ, ζ) pair is small, highlighting the similarity of these two structures. In the DFT study, however, the γ-isomer was found to be unstable in its crystal form and rearranged in the energy minimization to a more open ζ-like form. The 6-31g* optimization of the C  i -symmetry γ-isomer resulted in a small elongation of the central Mo-O bonds in the cluster and a more pronounced expansion along the length of the molecule to yield a clearly γ-like structure in contrast to the OFT study. This difference between the DFT and HF calculations seemed unusual enough to warrant a recalculation of the ζ-isomer from its symmetry-restricted C  i -crystal coordinates to determine if the resulting 3-21g (γ, ζ)-isomer pair may have been due to the choice of basis set. The new 6-31g* ζ-isomer was found to optimize, as was also found for the 3-21g (ε, η)-isomer pair, to the D 3d -symmetry α-isomer. With the optimization of the new ζ-, α-, and (ε, η)-isomers to a D 3d  minimum, the final count of unique isomers with the 6-31g* basis set is reduced to four. The new (α, ε, η, ζ)-isomer series lies 24 kJ/mol above the single δ-isomer, a difference in agreement with the 23 kJ/mol difference found for the 6-31g* single-point energy difference between the α- and δ-isomers. With the exception of the large energy difference between the α-isomer and the local minimum ε-isomer in the DFT calculations, the ordering and relative groupings of the seven isomers into four clearly unique structures are consistent with the DFT results.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">As noted above, energy minimization of the 3-21g structures with the 6-31g* basis set reduces the total number of unique isomers to four and divides these isomers into a local grouping of three and a far-lying, higher energy β-structure. The interconversion of the α- and β-isomers in solution again highlights the accessibility of all seven isomers based on 6-31g* energy differences, where five isomers are found to reside within an energy range less than 1/3 of the separation between the α- and β-isomers. In the α-isomer series, the rearrangement scheme shown in  to form η- and ζ-isomers is simply reversed back to the ε-isomer and back one last step to yield the more stable α-form. The γ-isomer is still found to be a local minimum structure with either basis set. While a straightforward rearrangement of the α- and δ-isomers can be employed to describe the interconversion of the two, these two low-energy structures still retain their unique shapes, respective bonding interactions, and relative energy difference. The 6-31g* bond lengths and bond orders are in remarkably good agreement with most of the experimental distances. Of the 55 unique Mo–O bonds in the four isomers, 45 differ from the crystallographic distance by less than 0.090<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The three bond lengths that differ by more than 0.250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å occur in the γ- and β-structures, which both undergo large structural changes that result in the displacement of molybdenum polyhedra from their crystallographic positions as will be described below.</ce:para>

The 6-31g* bond lengths and bond orders are in remarkably good agreement with most of the experimental distances. Of the 55 unique Mo-O bonds in the four isomers, 45 differ from the crystallographic distance by less than 0.090Å. The three bond lengths that differ by more than 0.250Å occur in the γ- and β-structures, which both undergo large structural changes that result in the displacement of molybdenum polyhedra from their crystallographic positions as will be described below.

<ce:section-title>δ-Isomer</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The Mo–O bond lengths and bond orders of the δ-isomer are given in  and the labeling scheme of the symmetry-unique atoms of the <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2<ce:italic>h</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> structure is provided in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG8"></ce:float-anchor>. The δ-isomer is composed of a Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> ring linked through otherwise unbound μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> oxygen atoms and bicapped by MoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> tetrahedra. Two of the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> ring molybdenum atoms (Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) are nearly tetrahedral MoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> subunits and connect to the structure only through μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> oxygen bonds. The possible assignment of a final pair of oxygen atoms to form a MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> arrangement of these two tetrahedra from two added Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> bonds is disfavored by the large (3.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) distance between these atoms and the nearly tetrahedral arrangement of the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> (O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>–Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>=113°) and Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> (O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>–Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>=106°) bond pairs. Four MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> (Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) subunits are joined pair-wise by edge-linked μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (O<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>) and μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) oxygen atoms and to the bicapping tetrahedral MoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> subunits by μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>) oxygen atoms. The capping tetrahedra are deformed slightly through coordination of the μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> O<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> atom and two μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> atoms to the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> ring. The μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> O<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> is bound least tightly to Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> relative to the terminal O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> as noted by the longer (1.856<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) bond and lower bond order (0.690). The μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> atoms are intermediate in both bond length (1.778<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and bond order (1.154) between the terminal O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> O<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> atoms.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
δ-Isomer

The Mo-O bond lengths and bond orders of the δ-isomer are given in  and the labeling scheme of the symmetry-unique atoms of the C 2h  structure is provided in  . The δ-isomer is composed of a Mo6O6 ring linked through otherwise unbound μ2 oxygen atoms and bicapped by MoO4 tetrahedra. Two of the Mo6O6 ring molybdenum atoms (Mo2) are nearly tetrahedral MoO4 subunits and connect to the structure only through μ2 oxygen bonds. The possible assignment of a final pair of oxygen atoms to form a MoO6 arrangement of these two tetrahedra from two added Mo2-O4 bonds is disfavored by the large (3.25Å) distance between these atoms and the nearly tetrahedral arrangement of the Mo2-O7 (O7-Mo2-O7=113°) and Mo2-O8 (O8-Mo2-O8=106°) bond pairs. Four MoO6 (Mo3) subunits are joined pair-wise by edge-linked μ3 (O1) and μ2 (O3) oxygen atoms and to the bicapping tetrahedral MoO4 subunits by μ2 (O4) oxygen atoms. The capping tetrahedra are deformed slightly through coordination of the μ3 O1 atom and two μ2 O4 atoms to the Mo6O6 ring. The μ3 O1 is bound least tightly to Mo1 relative to the terminal O2 as noted by the longer (1.856Å) bond and lower bond order (0.690). The μ2 O4 atoms are intermediate in both bond length (1.778Å) and bond order (1.154) between the terminal O2 and μ3 O1 atoms.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Geometry optimization of the δ-isomer reduces its energy relative to the crystal structure coordinates by 77.64 kJ/mol. With the exception of the longer Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> bonds, the Mo–O bonds of the δ-isomer are found to shrink slightly in the 6-31g* energy minimization relative to both the crystal coordinates and the 3-21g minimum energy structure. Simple inspection of the scaled crystal and 6-31g* geometries () reveals them to be nearly identical, with the calculated structure slightly elongating the apical Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–Mo′<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> distance to expand the central cavity.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Geometry optimization of the δ-isomer reduces its energy relative to the crystal structure coordinates by 77.64 kJ/mol. With the exception of the longer Mo3-O1 and Mo3-O7 bonds, the Mo-O bonds of the δ-isomer are found to shrink slightly in the 6-31g* energy minimization relative to both the crystal coordinates and the 3-21g minimum energy structure. Simple inspection of the scaled crystal and 6-31g* geometries () reveals them to be nearly identical, with the calculated structure slightly elongating the apical Mo1-Mo'1 distance to expand the central cavity.

The (α, η, ε, ζ)-isomer is composed of a Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> ring linked through otherwise unbound μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> oxygen atoms (O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>). The three O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atoms of the bicapping MoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> tetrahedra are used to complete the octahedral coordination spheres of the edge-linked equatorial MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> (Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) octahedral subunits. The μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> oxygen atoms (O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) remain strongly bound to the capping tetrahedra, coordinating to the octahedral Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atoms through long (2.522<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) bonds with small bond orders, effectively filling the vacant octahedral sites of Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> through an ionic interaction. The capping tetrahedra remain largely unchanged with O<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> angles of 110.6° and O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> angles of 108.4°. The energy change with optimization between the crystal coordinates and 6-31g* geometry is, at 75.70 kJ/mol, similar to that of the change noted for the δ-isomer. Excellent agreement between the α-crystallographic <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>i</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (nearly <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
