elements.clean_text:
(α, ε, η, ζ)-Isomers

The Mo-O bond lengths and bond orders of the (α, η, ε, ζ)-isomer are given in  and the labeling scheme for the symmetry-unique atoms of the D 3d  structure is provided in  . The (α, η, ε, ζ)-isomer is composed of a Mo6O6 ring linked through otherwise unbound μ2 oxygen atoms (O4). The three O2 atoms of the bicapping MoO4 tetrahedra are used to complete the octahedral coordination spheres of the edge-linked equatorial MoO6 (Mo2) octahedral subunits. The μ3 oxygen atoms (O2) remain strongly bound to the capping tetrahedra, coordinating to the octahedral Mo2 atoms through long (2.522Å) bonds with small bond orders, effectively filling the vacant octahedral sites of Mo2 through an ionic interaction. The capping tetrahedra remain largely unchanged with O1-Mo2-O1 angles of 110.6° and O2-Mo2-O2 angles of 108.4°. The energy change with optimization between the crystal coordinates and 6-31g* geometry is, at 75.70 kJ/mol, similar to that of the change noted for the δ-isomer. Excellent agreement between the α-crystallographic C  i  (nearly D 3d ) positions and the D 3d -symmetry 6-31g*-optimized atomic positions is noted for this isomer. Simple inspection of the scaled crystal and 6-31g* geometries () reveal them to be nearly identical.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The rearrangement mechanism of the ε-, η-, and ζ-isomers to the α-isomer is shown in . The rearrangement of the ε-isomer to the lower-energy α-isomer is a continuation of the same relaxation observed for the conversion of the η- to the ε-isomer. In the absence of coordinating metals, one pair of Mo–O bonds (Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> in ) is broken between the bicapping octahedral MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> subunits and the four square pyramidal MoO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> subunits in the ε-isomer. The rearrangement of the ζ- to the ε-isomer is a result of a small shift of the bicapping MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedra back to the <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2<ce:italic>h</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> mirror plane of the ε-isomer. The rearrangement of the ζ-isomer crystal coordinates to the α-isomer indicates that the γ–ε rearrangement pathway favoring the lower-energy γ-isomer in the 3-21g optimization is reversed with the 6-31g* basis set, and the ζ-isomer rearranges to the ε-isomer as shown in  before following the ε-isomer rearrangement pathway to the α-isomer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The rearrangement mechanism of the ε-, η-, and ζ-isomers to the α-isomer is shown in . The rearrangement of the ε-isomer to the lower-energy α-isomer is a continuation of the same relaxation observed for the conversion of the η- to the ε-isomer. In the absence of coordinating metals, one pair of Mo-O bonds (Mo1-O4 in ) is broken between the bicapping octahedral MoO6 subunits and the four square pyramidal MoO5 subunits in the ε-isomer. The rearrangement of the ζ- to the ε-isomer is a result of a small shift of the bicapping MoO6 octahedra back to the C 2h  mirror plane of the ε-isomer. The rearrangement of the ζ-isomer crystal coordinates to the α-isomer indicates that the γ-ε rearrangement pathway favoring the lower-energy γ-isomer in the 3-21g optimization is reversed with the 6-31g* basis set, and the ζ-isomer rearranges to the ε-isomer as shown in  before following the ε-isomer rearrangement pathway to the α-isomer.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>γ-Isomer</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The Mo–O bond lengths and bond orders of the γ-isomer are given in  and the labeling scheme for the symmetry-unique atoms of the <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>i</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> structure is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG10"></ce:float-anchor>. The familiar ring motif of the α- and δ-isomers is lost in the γ-isomer. The crystallographic identification of six octahedral and two square pyramidal subunits is altered in the 6-31g* optimizations to yield four square pyramidal and four octahedral subunits. The octahedron formed from Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> changes to a square pyramid with the elongation of the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf> bond from 2.533 to 3.448<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. This elongation is a common feature to the 3-21g, 6-31g*, and DFT calculations, and indicates that crystal constraints are likely responsible for enhancing the bonding character of this interaction. The second significant change in the structure of the γ-isomer with optimization is the elongation of the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–O′<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf> bonds to form a larger central cavity. The calculated bond order of the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–O′<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf> bond in the experimental γ-isomer structure is already low at 0.085. Optimization expands the bond length by 0.23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and decreases the bond order to 0.077. This increased separation causes a slight bending of the O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf> plane towards that expected for a square pyramidal structure. The Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> atom, however, remains octahedral relative to other distorted polyhedra in the isomers. Comparison of the crystal and 6-31g* structures of the γ-isomer () shows the significant structural changes that occur and the effect of these changes on the remainder of the structure. As expected, the energy difference between the crystal and 6-31g* geometries is quite large at 140.08 kJ/mol, nearly twice that for the α- and δ-isomer energy differences.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
γ-Isomer

The Mo-O bond lengths and bond orders of the γ-isomer are given in  and the labeling scheme for the symmetry-unique atoms of the C  i  structure is shown in  . The familiar ring motif of the α- and δ-isomers is lost in the γ-isomer. The crystallographic identification of six octahedral and two square pyramidal subunits is altered in the 6-31g* optimizations to yield four square pyramidal and four octahedral subunits. The octahedron formed from Mo1 changes to a square pyramid with the elongation of the Mo1-O11 bond from 2.533 to 3.448Å. This elongation is a common feature to the 3-21g, 6-31g*, and DFT calculations, and indicates that crystal constraints are likely responsible for enhancing the bonding character of this interaction. The second significant change in the structure of the γ-isomer with optimization is the elongation of the Mo3-O'11 bonds to form a larger central cavity. The calculated bond order of the Mo3-O'11 bond in the experimental γ-isomer structure is already low at 0.085. Optimization expands the bond length by 0.23Å and decreases the bond order to 0.077. This increased separation causes a slight bending of the O6-O10-O11-O9 plane towards that expected for a square pyramidal structure. The Mo3 atom, however, remains octahedral relative to other distorted polyhedra in the isomers. Comparison of the crystal and 6-31g* structures of the γ-isomer () shows the significant structural changes that occur and the effect of these changes on the remainder of the structure. As expected, the energy difference between the crystal and 6-31g* geometries is quite large at 140.08 kJ/mol, nearly twice that for the α- and δ-isomer energy differences.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>β-Isomer</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The Mo–O bond lengths and bond orders of the β-isomer are given in  and the labeling scheme for the symmetry-unique atoms of the <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2<ce:italic>h</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>-symmetry structure is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG11"></ce:float-anchor>. The changes in geometry of the β-isomer upon optimization are similar to those noted for the γ-isomer. Minimization of the β-isomer energy causes a 0.57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å displacement of the two Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> atoms away from the octahedral center of the cluster, reducing the apparent coordination of Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> from 6- to 5-coordinate and causing a change in the geometry of Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> to square pyramidal. This displacement in the DFT calculations is only 0.11<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The central region of the β-isomer is also found to expand in the 6-31g* optimizations. In the γ-isomer, this expansion occurred at two μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>) oxygen atoms. In the β-isomer, this same expansion occurs around two oxygen atoms that are μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> (O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>). This μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> coordination is reduced primarily by the large separation of the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> bond at either end of the structure. The increasingly μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-character oxygen atoms in the 6-31g* optimization then separate from their central Mo atoms (Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) to cause a expansion of the cluster in both the horizontal and vertical directions (). The expansion of the central region and peripheral Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> octahedra with energy minimization is clearly visible in the structure comparison shown in . The structural changes that occur with minimization lower the relative energy of the 6-31g* β-isomer by 121.26 kJ/mol, a value intermediate between the small structural changes noted in the α- and δ-isomers and the significant geometry changes that occur in the γ-isomer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
β-Isomer

The Mo-O bond lengths and bond orders of the β-isomer are given in  and the labeling scheme for the symmetry-unique atoms of the C 2h -symmetry structure is shown in  . The changes in geometry of the β-isomer upon optimization are similar to those noted for the γ-isomer. Minimization of the β-isomer energy causes a 0.57Å displacement of the two Mo1 atoms away from the octahedral center of the cluster, reducing the apparent coordination of Mo1 from 6- to 5-coordinate and causing a change in the geometry of Mo1 to square pyramidal. This displacement in the DFT calculations is only 0.11Å. The central region of the β-isomer is also found to expand in the 6-31g* optimizations. In the γ-isomer, this expansion occurred at two μ3 (O11) oxygen atoms. In the β-isomer, this same expansion occurs around two oxygen atoms that are μ5 (O7). This μ5 coordination is reduced primarily by the large separation of the Mo1-O7 bond at either end of the structure. The increasingly μ4-character oxygen atoms in the 6-31g* optimization then separate from their central Mo atoms (Mo3) to cause a expansion of the cluster in both the horizontal and vertical directions (). The expansion of the central region and peripheral Mo1 octahedra with energy minimization is clearly visible in the structure comparison shown in . The structural changes that occur with minimization lower the relative energy of the 6-31g* β-isomer by 121.26 kJ/mol, a value intermediate between the small structural changes noted in the α- and δ-isomers and the significant geometry changes that occur in the γ-isomer.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In light of the many similarities in final geometry between the 3-21g and 6-31g* structures, the defining differences between the two basis sets are the relative energies of the isomers and the resulting ordering of isomer stability based on energy minimization. The DFT and 6-31g* calculations predict the same overall ordering of the isomers by energy while disagreeing as to whether or not various isomers represent local minima (DFT) or transitional structures frozen by countercation coordination (6-31g*). The δ- and α-isomers in both the DFT and 6-31g* optimizations are the most stable of the known isomers in the absence of their crystal environments and the β-isomer is found to be least stable overall. Interestingly, the β-isomer is the most prevalent form among the available crystal structures, indicating the importance of considering interactions within the unit cell when predicting which isomer will appear. If the 6-31g* and DFT results are taken to yield the best energies and geometries, then the 3-21g structures are found to overestimate the binding within the (γ, ζ)-isomer pair, incorrectly predict stabilizing interactions in the (ε, η) pair, predict with reasonable accuracy the δ–α energy gap, and underestimate the instability of the β-isomer relative to the lowest energy (γ, ζ)-isomer and the higher-lying δ-isomer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In light of the many similarities in final geometry between the 3-21g and 6-31g* structures, the defining differences between the two basis sets are the relative energies of the isomers and the resulting ordering of isomer stability based on energy minimization. The DFT and 6-31g* calculations predict the same overall ordering of the isomers by energy while disagreeing as to whether or not various isomers represent local minima (DFT) or transitional structures frozen by countercation coordination (6-31g*). The δ- and α-isomers in both the DFT and 6-31g* optimizations are the most stable of the known isomers in the absence of their crystal environments and the β-isomer is found to be least stable overall. Interestingly, the β-isomer is the most prevalent form among the available crystal structures, indicating the importance of considering interactions within the unit cell when predicting which isomer will appear. If the 6-31g* and DFT results are taken to yield the best energies and geometries, then the 3-21g structures are found to overestimate the binding within the (γ, ζ)-isomer pair, incorrectly predict stabilizing interactions in the (ε, η) pair, predict with reasonable accuracy the δ-α energy gap, and underestimate the instability of the β-isomer relative to the lowest energy (γ, ζ)-isomer and the higher-lying δ-isomer.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The Mo–O bond orders associated with actual bonding interactions occur over a broad range of values, ranging from 1.832 for the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf> bond in the β-isomer to well below 0.250. It is clear from bond length analyses that μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> oxygen atoms preferentially bind more tightly to different metal centers than others based on structural restrictions, the formal coordination sphere of the molybdenum atom, proximity to other oxygen atoms, etc. Further, it is clear that not all terminal oxygen atoms are equivalent, given the existence of tetrahedral, octahedral, and square pyramidal molybdenum centers in these isomers. Finally, it is apparent in the α- and δ-isomers that μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> oxygen atoms show obvious preference for coordination to the capping tetrahedra and bind much less strongly to the equatorial Mo octahedral. In order to gauge these various interactions in a more descriptive manner, the Mulliken charges of the oxygen atoms are plotted vs. the sum of the bond orders associated with each oxygen atom in the four unique isomers obtained from the 6-31g* calculations. Both Mulliken and Löwdin charges are provided in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL10"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL11"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL12"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL13"></ce:float-anchor> for the symmetry unique atoms of the 6-31g* energy minima. The familiar basis set dependence of these electron partitioning methods is demonstrated in comparing the 6-31g* charges with those obtained from the 3-21g calculations. While Mulliken charges are used here for the analysis of oxygen coordination, the trends as examined by Löwdin charge analyses are found to be nearly identical. The linear correlation between the Mulliken charges and bond orders is coupled with the structural analyses of the isomers to better understand the relative degrees of coordination of the unique oxygen atoms in these structures and develop some greater intuition for the binding interactions in these structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The Mo-O bond orders associated with actual bonding interactions occur over a broad range of values, ranging from 1.832 for the Mo3-O9 bond in the β-isomer to well below 0.250. It is clear from bond length analyses that μ2 oxygen atoms preferentially bind more tightly to different metal centers than others based on structural restrictions, the formal coordination sphere of the molybdenum atom, proximity to other oxygen atoms, etc. Further, it is clear that not all terminal oxygen atoms are equivalent, given the existence of tetrahedral, octahedral, and square pyramidal molybdenum centers in these isomers. Finally, it is apparent in the α- and δ-isomers that μ3 oxygen atoms show obvious preference for coordination to the capping tetrahedra and bind much less strongly to the equatorial Mo octahedral. In order to gauge these various interactions in a more descriptive manner, the Mulliken charges of the oxygen atoms are plotted vs. the sum of the bond orders associated with each oxygen atom in the four unique isomers obtained from the 6-31g* calculations. Both Mulliken and Löwdin charges are provided in      for the symmetry unique atoms of the 6-31g* energy minima. The familiar basis set dependence of these electron partitioning methods is demonstrated in comparing the 6-31g* charges with those obtained from the 3-21g calculations. While Mulliken charges are used here for the analysis of oxygen coordination, the trends as examined by Löwdin charge analyses are found to be nearly identical. The linear correlation between the Mulliken charges and bond orders is coupled with the structural analyses of the isomers to better understand the relative degrees of coordination of the unique oxygen atoms in these structures and develop some greater intuition for the binding interactions in these structures.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The range of terminal oxygen atoms is encompassed in region A of 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG12"></ce:float-anchor>. The resulting Mulliken charges and bond orders for these oxygen atoms indicate isolation to localized Mo–O interactions within each isomer in the form of double bonds. The terminal oxygen atoms of the MoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> tetrahedra are generally found at the low end (1.6–1.7) of this bond order range, increasing through the square pyramidal MoO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> to the octahedral MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> polyhedra. The wide range of bond orders in this region is due to the variety of tetrahedral- through octahedral-type metal centers in the four 6-31g* isomers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The range of terminal oxygen atoms is encompassed in region A of  . The resulting Mulliken charges and bond orders for these oxygen atoms indicate isolation to localized Mo-O interactions within each isomer in the form of double bonds. The terminal oxygen atoms of the MoO4 tetrahedra are generally found at the low end (1.6-1.7) of this bond order range, increasing through the square pyramidal MoO5 to the octahedral MoO6 polyhedra. The wide range of bond orders in this region is due to the variety of tetrahedral- through octahedral-type metal centers in the four 6-31g* isomers.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The region of the Mulliken/bond order plot encompassed by region B is unique both for its localization to an otherwise unpopulated region and because of the origins of the points in the isomers. The points correspond to β-isomer atom O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and γ-isomer atom O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>. These two atoms typify instances where a formal bond is assigned between metal and ligand but the actual interaction is quite limited. In the β-isomer, atom O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> is bound to the octahedral Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> atom with a bond length of 1.719<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and a bond order of 1.326. This Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> bond is slightly elongated from those belonging to the terminal oxygen class, and the bond order is intermediate between that of a terminal oxygen and an μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> oxygen. The second interaction involving atom O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> is to Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>, a metal identified as octahedral in the crystallographic coordinates but increasingly square pyramidal in the 6-31g* geometry optimizations. The Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> bond length of 2.403<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å corresponds to a bond order of only 0.162. The Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> atom is, in the 6-31g* optimization, found to approach a nearly tetrahedral geometry with a O<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> bond angle of 103° and an O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–O′<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> bond angle of 124°. The Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> bond of the crystal structure is virtually non-existent in the optimized structure, and the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> bond in the crystal structure becomes only a weak interaction.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The region of the Mulliken/bond order plot encompassed by region B is unique both for its localization to an otherwise unpopulated region and because of the origins of the points in the isomers. The points correspond to β-isomer atom O4 and γ-isomer atom O9. These two atoms typify instances where a formal bond is assigned between metal and ligand but the actual interaction is quite limited. In the β-isomer, atom O4 is bound to the octahedral Mo3 atom with a bond length of 1.719Å and a bond order of 1.326. This Mo3-O4 bond is slightly elongated from those belonging to the terminal oxygen class, and the bond order is intermediate between that of a terminal oxygen and an μ2 oxygen. The second interaction involving atom O4 is to Mo1, a metal identified as octahedral in the crystallographic coordinates but increasingly square pyramidal in the 6-31g* geometry optimizations. The Mo1-O4 bond length of 2.403Å corresponds to a bond order of only 0.162. The Mo1 atom is, in the 6-31g* optimization, found to approach a nearly tetrahedral geometry with a O1-Mo1-O2 bond angle of 103° and an O3-Mo1-O'3 bond angle of 124°. The Mo1-O7 bond of the crystal structure is virtually non-existent in the optimized structure, and the Mo1-O4 bond in the crystal structure becomes only a weak interaction.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">A similar change occurs in the γ-isomer upon optimization. Atom O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf> is bound to Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> with a bond length of 1.721<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and a bond order of 1.305, both values consistent with the O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> atom of the β-isomer. The second formal bond, between Mo<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>, is 2.371<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å with a bond order of 0.191, also consistent in magnitude with the longer Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> bond in the β-isomer. Appropriately, β-O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and γ-O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf> bridge the gap between typical terminal oxygen atoms and the μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> series localized to region C. Their intermediate status and large differences in bond orders would indicate either that the geometries of the two isomers prohibit better interactions due to cluster expansion or that these particular oxygen atoms are formally bound to one molybdenum and coordinated to a second molybdenum by weaker lone pair interactions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A similar change occurs in the γ-isomer upon optimization. Atom O9 is bound to Mo3 with a bond length of 1.721Å and a bond order of 1.305, both values consistent with the O4 atom of the β-isomer. The second formal bond, between Mo4 and O9, is 2.371Å with a bond order of 0.191, also consistent in magnitude with the longer Mo1-O4 bond in the β-isomer. Appropriately, β-O4 and γ-O9 bridge the gap between typical terminal oxygen atoms and the μ2/μ3 series localized to region C. Their intermediate status and large differences in bond orders would indicate either that the geometries of the two isomers prohibit better interactions due to cluster expansion or that these particular oxygen atoms are formally bound to one molybdenum and coordinated to a second molybdenum by weaker lone pair interactions.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The range encompassed in region C accounts for the vast of the formally assigned μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> oxygen atoms. Within the range of total bond orders and Mulliken charges, there are no obvious trends to be drawn and the μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> oxo groups exist over the entire region. The lack of clear divisions in the μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-oxo and μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-oxo groupings stems from the relative degrees to which an oxygen can be μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>- or μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-coordinated to metal centers. The strong bond/weak interaction limit of μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-character exhibited by the β- and γ-oxygens in region B is progressively leveled as the μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> oxygens are more evenly shared between metal centers. This even distribution of oxygen atoms is exemplified in the high symmetry α(O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)- and δ(O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)-isomers, where single oxygens are shared between symmetry-related molybdenum atoms. In the δ-isomer, three unique types of μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-oxygen atoms are present. Where the oxygen is shared between a tetrahedral MoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and an octahedral MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, bonding is enhanced to the tetrahedron. In the α-isomer, all μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-oxygens are equally shared between neighboring molybdenum atoms, resulting in notably longer (1.910<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) bond lengths and smaller (0.604) bond orders compared to singly bound oxygens. The varying degrees of μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-oxygen coordination are also demonstrated in the wide distribution of values between bond order sums of 1.2 and 1.4. The μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> oxygen (O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>) of the γ-isomer is also included in this range. The already weak interactions between Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and O′<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf> and Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf> are further diminished in the 6-31g* optimization by the enlarging of the central cavity and displacement of the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> octahedron from the center of the isomer to yield a square pyramidal coordination site.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The range encompassed in region C accounts for the vast of the formally assigned μ2 and μ3 oxygen atoms. Within the range of total bond orders and Mulliken charges, there are no obvious trends to be drawn and the μ2 and μ3 oxo groups exist over the entire region. The lack of clear divisions in the μ2-oxo and μ3-oxo groupings stems from the relative degrees to which an oxygen can be μ2- or μ3-coordinated to metal centers. The strong bond/weak interaction limit of μ2-character exhibited by the β- and γ-oxygens in region B is progressively leveled as the μ2 oxygens are more evenly shared between metal centers. This even distribution of oxygen atoms is exemplified in the high symmetry α(O4)- and δ(O3)-isomers, where single oxygens are shared between symmetry-related molybdenum atoms. In the δ-isomer, three unique types of μ2-oxygen atoms are present. Where the oxygen is shared between a tetrahedral MoO4 and an octahedral MoO6, bonding is enhanced to the tetrahedron. In the α-isomer, all μ2-oxygens are equally shared between neighboring molybdenum atoms, resulting in notably longer (1.910Å) bond lengths and smaller (0.604) bond orders compared to singly bound oxygens. The varying degrees of μ3-oxygen coordination are also demonstrated in the wide distribution of values between bond order sums of 1.2 and 1.4. The μ4 oxygen (O11) of the γ-isomer is also included in this range. The already weak interactions between Mo3 and O'11 and Mo1 and O11 are further diminished in the 6-31g* optimization by the enlarging of the central cavity and displacement of the Mo1 octahedron from the center of the isomer to yield a square pyramidal coordination site.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">At the far end of the Mulliken/bond order plot is region D, where the three most heavily shared oxygen atoms of all of the isomers reside. In the 6-31g* optimized γ-isomer, O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> is shared between two square pyramidal molybdenum subunits (Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) and one octahedron (Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>). Atom O<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf> is shared between two octahedra (Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and Mo<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>) and one square pyramid (Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>). The bond order of O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> to its coordinated molybdenum sites decreases in the order Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and the strongest of these bonds, at 1.922<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å with order of 0.519, is the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> bond. Atom O<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf> is bound most strongly to the square pyramidal Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, the molybdenum with the fewest coordinated oxygens of the three. The μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> oxygen of the crystallographic β-isomer is embedded within a region of five octahedral molybdenum subunits. The 6-31g* energy minimization displaces one of these coordinated molybdenum atoms as to effectively break one Mo–O interaction. The optimization also enlarges the center of the isomer by diminishing the bonding character of the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> interaction. These two structural changes reduce the μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-coordination to something approaching the μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-type environment of the γ-isomer μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> oxygens, though the close-packed structure and limited deformation of the β-isomer still keeps the actual binding of the oxygen atom high.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: At the far end of the Mulliken/bond order plot is region D, where the three most heavily shared oxygen atoms of all of the isomers reside. In the 6-31g* optimized γ-isomer, O6 is shared between two square pyramidal molybdenum subunits (Mo1 and Mo2) and one octahedron (Mo3). Atom O10 is shared between two octahedra (Mo3 and Mo4) and one square pyramid (Mo2). The bond order of O6 to its coordinated molybdenum sites decreases in the order Mo3>Mo2>Mo1 and the strongest of these bonds, at 1.922Å with order of 0.519, is the Mo3-O6 bond. Atom O10 is bound most strongly to the square pyramidal Mo2, the molybdenum with the fewest coordinated oxygens of the three. The μ5 oxygen of the crystallographic β-isomer is embedded within a region of five octahedral molybdenum subunits. The 6-31g* energy minimization displaces one of these coordinated molybdenum atoms as to effectively break one Mo-O interaction. The optimization also enlarges the center of the isomer by diminishing the bonding character of the Mo3-O7 interaction. These two structural changes reduce the μ5-coordination to something approaching the μ3-type environment of the γ-isomer μ3 oxygens, though the close-packed structure and limited deformation of the β-isomer still keeps the actual binding of the oxygen atom high.

The octamolybdate subunit consists of four MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedra and four MoO<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> square pyramids and represents a new variant designated as ζ-{Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The hydrothermal reaction of CuSO4⋅5H2O, MoO3 and tetra-2-pyridylpyrazine yields a three-dimensional bimetallic oxide [{Cu2(tpyrpyz)}2{Mo8O26}]⋅7H2O, constructed from {Cu2(tpyrpyz)} n  2n+ coordination polymer chains tethered through octamolybdate clusters. The octamolybdate subunit consists of four MoO6 octahedra and four MoO8 square pyramids and represents a new variant designated as ζ-{Mo8O26}4-.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">A significant basis set dependence is found in these octamolybdates, with the results of the 3-21g and 6-31g* calculations differing in relative energies, relative orderings, the calculation of stable local minima in two cases (ε, ζ), certain structural features, and calculated charge densities. A discrepancy exists between some of the DFT and RHF/6-31g* results of isolated isomers stabilities concerning their occurrence as local minima (DFT) versus their existence as coordination-dependent transition structures by deformation of lower energy parent isomers (RHF), but both methods agree that these isomers exist within a narrow energy range. The β-isomer is the highest in energy according to single-point calculations and energy minimizations with both basis sets. The α- and δ-isomers are the most stable according to the 6-31g* calculations and previously reported DFT results. Rational isomerization pathways based on relative energies and common structural features are described.</ce:para>

A discrepancy exists between some of the DFT and RHF/6-31g* results of isolated isomers stabilities concerning their occurrence as local minima (DFT) versus their existence as coordination-dependent transition structures by deformation of lower energy parent isomers (RHF), but both methods agree that these isomers exist within a narrow energy range. The β-isomer is the highest in energy according to single-point calculations and energy minimizations with both basis sets. The α- and δ-isomers are the most stable according to the 6-31g* calculations and previously reported DFT results. Rational isomerization pathways based on relative energies and common structural features are described.

The infrared spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibited strong bands in the 800–960 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> range, attributed to <ce:italic>υ</ce:italic>(MoO) and <ce:italic>υ</ce:italic>(M–O–Mo) [M=Cu or Mo]. cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [{Cu2(tpyrpyz)}2Mo8O26]⋅7H2O (1⋅7H2O)

A mixture of CuSO4⋅5H2O (0.046 g, 0.19 mmol), MoO3 (0.027 g, 0.19 mmol), tetra-4-pyridylpyrazine (0.108 g, 0.28 mmol) and H2O (10.0 g, 0.56 mol) in the mole ratio 1:1:1.5:3000 was heated at 120 °C for 48 h. Orange crystals of 1⋅7H2O were obtained in 30% yield based on molybdenum. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3400 (m, br), 1380 (s), 910 (s, br), 850 (m), 810 (s).

Results and discussion

Synthesis and structural studies

The bimetallic oxide of this study was prepared by conventional hydrothermal methods, which avoid thermal decomposition of the organic component while providing conditions which overcome the differential solubilities of the organic and inorganic components and which are optimal for crystal growth . In this fashion, the reaction of CuSO4⋅5H2O, MoO3 and tetra-2-pyridylpyrazine yielded [{Cu2(tpyrpyz)}2Mo8O26]⋅7H2O (1⋅7H2O) in 60% yield as dark blue crystals. The infrared spectrum of 1 exhibited strong bands in the 800-960 cm-1 range, attributed to υ(MoO) and υ(M-O-Mo) [M=Cu or Mo]. A group of peaks in the 1000-1500 cm-1 region is characteristic of the tpyrpyz ligand.

The crystallographic identification of six octahedral and two square pyramidal subunits is altered in the 6-31g* optimizations to yield four square pyramidal and four octahedral subunits. The octahedron formed from Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> changes to a square pyramid with the elongation of the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf> bond from 2.533 to 3.448<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. This elongation is a common feature to the 3-21g, 6-31g*, and DFT calculations, and indicates that crystal constraints are likely responsible for enhancing the bonding character of this interaction. The second significant change in the structure of the γ-isomer with optimization is the elongation of the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–O′<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf> bonds to form a larger central cavity. The calculated bond order of the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–O′<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf> bond in the experimental γ-isomer structure is already low at 0.085. Optimization expands the bond length by 0.23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and decreases the bond order to 0.077. This increased separation causes a slight bending of the O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf> plane towards that expected for a square pyramidal structure. The Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> atom, however, remains octahedral relative to other distorted polyhedra in the isomers. Comparison of the crystal and 6-31g* structures of the γ-isomer () shows the significant structural changes that occur and the effect of these changes on the remainder of the structure. As expected, the energy difference between the crystal and 6-31g* geometries is quite large at 140.08 kJ/mol, nearly twice that for the α- and δ-isomer energy differences.</ce:para><ce:section-title>β-Isomer</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The Mo–O bond lengths and bond orders of the β-isomer are given in  and the labeling scheme for the symmetry-unique atoms of the <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2<ce:italic>h</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>-symmetry structure is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG11"></ce:float-anchor>. The changes in geometry of the β-isomer upon optimization are similar to those noted for the γ-isomer. Minimization of the β-isomer energy causes a 0.57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å displacement of the two Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> atoms away from the octahedral center of the cluster, reducing the apparent coordination of Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> from 6- to 5-coordinate and causing a change in the geometry of Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> to square pyramidal. This displacement in the DFT calculations is only 0.11<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The central region of the β-isomer is also found to expand in the 6-31g* optimizations. In the γ-isomer, this expansion occurred at two μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>) oxygen atoms. In the β-isomer, this same expansion occurs around two oxygen atoms that are μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> (O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>). This μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> coordination is reduced primarily by the large separation of the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> bond at either end of the structure. The increasingly μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-character oxygen atoms in the 6-31g* optimization then separate from their central Mo atoms (Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) to cause a expansion of the cluster in both the horizontal and vertical directions (). The expansion of the central region and peripheral Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> octahedra with energy minimization is clearly visible in the structure comparison shown in . The structural changes that occur with minimization lower the relative energy of the 6-31g* β-isomer by 121.26 kJ/mol, a value intermediate between the small structural changes noted in the α- and δ-isomers and the significant geometry changes that occur in the γ-isomer.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Hydrothermal reactions of CuSO4⋅5H2O, MoO3 and tetra-2-pyridylpyrazine (tpyrpyz) yield the three-dimensional bimetallic oxide hybrid material [{Cu2(tpyrpyz)}2{ζ-Mo8O26}]⋅7H2O (1⋅7H2O). The framework structure is constructed from {Cu2(tpyrpyz)} n  2n+ cationic polymer chains linked through octamolybdate clusters. The ζ-isomer of {Mo8O26}4-, consisting of four octahedral and four square pyramidal sites is present as the cluster building block. There are now seven isomeric forms of the {Mo8O26}4- cluster, and calculations of their relative energies and interconversions are presented. Crystal data: C48H46Cu4Mo8N12O33 (1⋅7H2O), monoclinic C2/c, a=26.678(1), b=10.8981(4), and c=25.4109(9)Å, β=116.855(1)°, V=6591.2(4)Å3, Z=4, D calc=2.359gcm-3.

Single-point energies and isomerization pathways

The relative single-point energies of the seven isomers with both the 3-21g and 6-31g* oxygen basis sets are given in  . All values are reported relative to the δ-isomer, which is the lowest energy form in the RHF calculations. The calculations agree on the relative ordering of the energy extrema (the δ-, η-, and β-isomers) and the relative position of the ε-isomer. The major differences are in the ordering of the α-, ζ-, and γ-isomer energies and the energy ranges of the 3-21g and 6-31g* structures. With both basis sets, the ε-, ζ-, and γ-isomers occur within a narrow energy range (ε-γ=21.96 kJ/mol for 6-31g*; ζ-γ=30.53 kJ/mol for 3-21g). The α-isomer is included, at 15.42 kJ/mol, in this narrow energy series for the 3-21g calculations but is excluded, at 43.01 kJ/mol, in the 6-31g* series.

δ-Isomer

The Mo-O bond lengths and bond orders of the δ-isomer are given in  and the labeling scheme of the symmetry-unique atoms of the C 2h  structure is provided in  . The δ-isomer is composed of a Mo6O6 ring linked through otherwise unbound μ2 oxygen atoms and bicapped by MoO4 tetrahedra. Two of the Mo6O6 ring molybdenum atoms (Mo2) are nearly tetrahedral MoO4 subunits and connect to the structure only through μ2 oxygen bonds. The possible assignment of a final pair of oxygen atoms to form a MoO6 arrangement of these two tetrahedra from two added Mo2-O4 bonds is disfavored by the large (3.25Å) distance between these atoms and the nearly tetrahedral arrangement of the Mo2-O7 (O7-Mo2-O7=113°) and Mo2-O8 (O8-Mo2-O8=106°) bond pairs. Four MoO6 (Mo3) subunits are joined pair-wise by edge-linked μ3 (O1) and μ2 (O3) oxygen atoms and to the bicapping tetrahedral MoO4 subunits by μ2 (O4) oxygen atoms. The capping tetrahedra are deformed slightly through coordination of the μ3 O1 atom and two μ2 O4 atoms to the Mo6O6 ring. The μ3 O1 is bound least tightly to Mo1 relative to the terminal O2 as noted by the longer (1.856Å) bond and lower bond order (0.690). The μ2 O4 atoms are intermediate in both bond length (1.778Å) and bond order (1.154) between the terminal O2 and μ3 O1 atoms.

(α, ε, η, ζ)-Isomers

The Mo-O bond lengths and bond orders of the (α, η, ε, ζ)-isomer are given in  and the labeling scheme for the symmetry-unique atoms of the D 3d  structure is provided in  . The (α, η, ε, ζ)-isomer is composed of a Mo6O6 ring linked through otherwise unbound μ2 oxygen atoms (O4). The three O2 atoms of the bicapping MoO4 tetrahedra are used to complete the octahedral coordination spheres of the edge-linked equatorial MoO6 (Mo2) octahedral subunits. The μ3 oxygen atoms (O2) remain strongly bound to the capping tetrahedra, coordinating to the octahedral Mo2 atoms through long (2.522Å) bonds with small bond orders, effectively filling the vacant octahedral sites of Mo2 through an ionic interaction. The capping tetrahedra remain largely unchanged with O1-Mo2-O1 angles of 110.6° and O2-Mo2-O2 angles of 108.4°. The energy change with optimization between the crystal coordinates and 6-31g* geometry is, at 75.70 kJ/mol, similar to that of the change noted for the δ-isomer. Excellent agreement between the α-crystallographic C  i  (nearly D 3d ) positions and the D 3d -symmetry 6-31g*-optimized atomic positions is noted for this isomer. Simple inspection of the scaled crystal and 6-31g* geometries () reveal them to be nearly identical.

γ-Isomer

The Mo-O bond lengths and bond orders of the γ-isomer are given in  and the labeling scheme for the symmetry-unique atoms of the C  i  structure is shown in  . The familiar ring motif of the α- and δ-isomers is lost in the γ-isomer. The crystallographic identification of six octahedral and two square pyramidal subunits is altered in the 6-31g* optimizations to yield four square pyramidal and four octahedral subunits. The octahedron formed from Mo1 changes to a square pyramid with the elongation of the Mo1-O11 bond from 2.533 to 3.448Å. This elongation is a common feature to the 3-21g, 6-31g*, and DFT calculations, and indicates that crystal constraints are likely responsible for enhancing the bonding character of this interaction. The second significant change in the structure of the γ-isomer with optimization is the elongation of the Mo3-O'11 bonds to form a larger central cavity. The calculated bond order of the Mo3-O'11 bond in the experimental γ-isomer structure is already low at 0.085. Optimization expands the bond length by 0.23Å and decreases the bond order to 0.077. This increased separation causes a slight bending of the O6-O10-O11-O9 plane towards that expected for a square pyramidal structure. The Mo3 atom, however, remains octahedral relative to other distorted polyhedra in the isomers. Comparison of the crystal and 6-31g* structures of the γ-isomer () shows the significant structural changes that occur and the effect of these changes on the remainder of the structure. As expected, the energy difference between the crystal and 6-31g* geometries is quite large at 140.08 kJ/mol, nearly twice that for the α- and δ-isomer energy differences.

β-Isomer

The Mo-O bond lengths and bond orders of the β-isomer are given in  and the labeling scheme for the symmetry-unique atoms of the C 2h -symmetry structure is shown in  . The changes in geometry of the β-isomer upon optimization are similar to those noted for the γ-isomer. Minimization of the β-isomer energy causes a 0.57Å displacement of the two Mo1 atoms away from the octahedral center of the cluster, reducing the apparent coordination of Mo1 from 6- to 5-coordinate and causing a change in the geometry of Mo1 to square pyramidal. This displacement in the DFT calculations is only 0.11Å. The central region of the β-isomer is also found to expand in the 6-31g* optimizations. In the γ-isomer, this expansion occurred at two μ3 (O11) oxygen atoms. In the β-isomer, this same expansion occurs around two oxygen atoms that are μ5 (O7). This μ5 coordination is reduced primarily by the large separation of the Mo1-O7 bond at either end of the structure. The increasingly μ4-character oxygen atoms in the 6-31g* optimization then separate from their central Mo atoms (Mo3) to cause a expansion of the cluster in both the horizontal and vertical directions (). The expansion of the central region and peripheral Mo1 octahedra with energy minimization is clearly visible in the structure comparison shown in . The structural changes that occur with minimization lower the relative energy of the 6-31g* β-isomer by 121.26 kJ/mol, a value intermediate between the small structural changes noted in the α- and δ-isomers and the significant geometry changes that occur in the γ-isomer.

cln_elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The region of the Mulliken/bond order plot encompassed by region B is unique both for its localization to an otherwise unpopulated region and because of the origins of the points in the isomers. The points correspond to β-isomer atom O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and γ-isomer atom O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>. These two atoms typify instances where a formal bond is assigned between metal and ligand but the actual interaction is quite limited. In the β-isomer, atom O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> is bound to the octahedral Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> atom with a bond length of 1.719<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and a bond order of 1.326. This Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> bond is slightly elongated from those belonging to the terminal oxygen class, and the bond order is intermediate between that of a terminal oxygen and an μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> oxygen. The second interaction involving atom O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> is to Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>, a metal identified as octahedral in the crystallographic coordinates but increasingly square pyramidal in the 6-31g* geometry optimizations. The Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> bond length of 2.403<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å corresponds to a bond order of only 0.162. The Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> atom is, in the 6-31g* optimization, found to approach a nearly tetrahedral geometry with a O<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> bond angle of 103° and an O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–O′<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> bond angle of 124°. The Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> bond of the crystal structure is virtually non-existent in the optimized structure, and the Mo<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> bond in the crystal structure becomes only a weak interaction.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text: The region of the Mulliken/bond order plot encompassed by region B is unique both for its localization to an otherwise unpopulated region and because of the origins of the points in the isomers. The points correspond to β-isomer atom O4 and γ-isomer atom O9. These two atoms typify instances where a formal bond is assigned between metal and ligand but the actual interaction is quite limited. In the β-isomer, atom O4 is bound to the octahedral Mo3 atom with a bond length of 1.719Å and a bond order of 1.326. This Mo3-O4 bond is slightly elongated from those belonging to the terminal oxygen class, and the bond order is intermediate between that of a terminal oxygen and an μ2 oxygen. The second interaction involving atom O4 is to Mo1, a metal identified as octahedral in the crystallographic coordinates but increasingly square pyramidal in the 6-31g* geometry optimizations. The Mo1-O4 bond length of 2.403Å corresponds to a bond order of only 0.162. The Mo1 atom is, in the 6-31g* optimization, found to approach a nearly tetrahedral geometry with a O1-Mo1-O2 bond angle of 103° and an O3-Mo1-O'3 bond angle of 124°. The Mo1-O7 bond of the crystal structure is virtually non-existent in the optimized structure, and the Mo1-O4 bond in the crystal structure becomes only a weak interaction.

| Isomer | Example(s) | Polyhedral subunits | Number of oxo-groups and type | References |
|--------|------------|---------------------|-------------------------------|------------|
| α      | [{Cu(bpe)}4Mo8O26] | 6 octahedra, 2 tetrahedra | 14 | 6 | 6 |  |  | [24] |
|        | [Cu2(tpyrpyz)(H2O)2Mo8O26] |  |  |  |  |  |  | [25] |
|        | [{Cu(pyr)3}2{Cu(pyr)2}2Mo8O26] |  |  |  |  |  |  | [48] |
|        | [Cu4(dpp)4Mo8O26] |  |  |  |  |  |  | [47] |
| β      | [Cu4(Me-pyz)2Mo8O26] | 8 octahedra | 14 | 6 | 4 |  | 2 | [39] |
|        | [Cu4(Me2-pyrd)2Mo8O26] |  |  |  |  |  |  | [39] |
|        | [Cu2(pca)2Mo8O26] |  |  |  |  |  |  | [40] |
|        | [Cu3(pca)3(MoO4)Mo8O26] |  |  |  |  |  |  | [40] |
|        | [{Cu(S-pyr2)}4Mo8O26] |  |  |  |  |  |  | [29] |
|        | [{Cu3(phen)3}2(Mo6O19)(Mo8O26)] |  |  |  |  |  |  | [27] |
|        | [{Cu(4,4′-bpy)(nic)}2Mo8O26] |  |  |  |  |  |  | [41] |
|        | [Cu2(bpy)2Mo8O26] |  |  |  |  |  |  | [48] |
| γ      | [Me3N(CH2)6NMe3][Mo8O26] | 6 octahedra, 2 square pyramids | 14 | 6 | 4 | 2 |  | [49] |
|        | [{Cu(pyrd)}4Mo8O26] |  |  |  |  |  |  | [24] |

| δ      | [(RhCp∗)2(SCH3)3]4[Mo8O26] | 4 octahedra | 14 | 10 | 2 |  |  | [61] |

| α     | +23.00 | +23.00 | ζ     | +20.68 | +20.68 | δ     | +12   | +12   |
| ε     | +66.00 | +43.01 | ε     | +33.57 | +12.89 | γ     | +31   | +19   |
| ζ     | +83.04 | +17.04 | γ     | +51.22 | +17.65 | ε     | +43   | +12   |
| γ     | +97.96 | +14.92 | α     | +66.63 | +15.42 | ζ[^b] | +69   | +26   |
| η     | +158.66 | +60.70 | η     | +104.86 | +38.23 | β     | +79   | +10   |
| β     | +193.20 | +34.54 | β     | +110.74 | +5.88  |       |       |       |

[^a]: Values taken from Ref. [55].
[^b]: The ζ-isomer used for this study is intermediate between the ζ-isomer reported here and the γ-isomer.

Both the energy differences relative to the lowest-energy form (relative) and the energy difference between neighboring isomers (neighbor) are provided.

Table 5. Relative energies (in kJ/mol) of the geometry-optimized octamolybdate isomers

|        | 6-31g* | 6-31g* |        | 3-21g | 3-21g |        | BP86/opt | BP86/opt |
|--------|--------|--------|--------|-------|-------|--------|----------|----------|
|        | ΔE relative | ΔE neighbor |        | ΔE relative | ΔE neighbor |        | ΔE relative[^a] | ΔE neighbor[^a] |
| δ      | 0.000  | 0.000  | γ, ζ | 0.000 | 0.000 | δ      | 0        | 0        |
| α, η, ε, ζ | +24.343 | +24.343 | δ | +47.663 | +47.663 | α | +4 | +4 |
| γ (ζ[^b]) | +35.215 | +10.871 | ε, η | +57.702 | +10.039 | γ | +21 | +17 |
| β      | +149.188 | +113.973 | α | +75.913 | +18.208 | ζ[^c] | +31 | +10 |
|        |        |        | β | +85.383 | +9.470 | ε | +62 | +31 |
|        |        |        |        |       |       | β | +112 | +50 |

[^a]: Values taken from Ref. [55].
[^b]: The ζ-isomer optimized to either the γ-isomer or the α-isomer depending on the starting coordinates. See text.
[^c]: The ζ-isomer used for this study is intermediate between the ζ-isomer reported here and the γ-isomer.

Both the energy differences relative to the lowest-energy form (relative) and the energy difference between neighboring isomers (neighbor) are provided.

Table 7. α-Isomer (and 6-31g* optimized ε-, η-, and ζ-isomers) bond lengths and bond orders for the experimental and optimized 3-21g and 6-31g* structures

| Metal site | Isomer bond[^a] | Experimental[^b] | 3-21g Optimized |  |  | 6-31g* Optimized |  |  |
|------------|-----------------|------------------|-----------------|-----------------|-----------------|------------------|-----------------|-----------------|
|            |                 | Length (Å)       | Bond order 3-21g | Bond order 6-31g | Length (Å)       | Bond order       | Length (Å)       | Bond order       |
| Tetrahedral| Mo1–O1 (2)       | 1.710            | 2.014           | 1.660           | 1.716           | 2.019            | 1.698           | 1.627           |
|            | Mo1–O2 (6)       | 1.783            | 1.198           | 0.986           | 1.800           | 1.215            | 1.779           | 0.995           |
| Octahedral | Mo2–O2 (12)      | 2.424            | 0.289           | 0.143           | 2.455           | 0.284            | 2.522           | 0.153           |
|            | Mo2–O3 (12)      | 1.689            | 2.081           | 1.720           | 1.712           | 2.077            | 1.679           | 1.709           |
|            | Mo2–O4 (12)      | 1.909            | 0.818           | 0.608           | 1.903           | 0.816            | 1.910           | 0.604           |

[^a]: Atom labels are shown in Fig. 9. The number of bonds per isomer is given in parentheses for each.
[^b]: Average experimental bond lengths and bond orders are given.
data: Bond & Angle type of table is not target
